When I told Katherine about their strange behavior before the fighting started, she blanched.
Then she stared at him as one that is stricken, and her face blanched, and for long she spoke no more, while all sat silent.

The serving men brought out a heron stuffed with figs, veal cutlets blanched with almond milk, creamed herring, candied onions, foul-smelling cheeses, plates of snails and sweetbreads, and a black swan in her plumage.

bobby.description: an informal term for a British policeman
shorts: (noun) an informal term for a British policeman
examples: Her hair falls past her shoulders in loose waves, not a bobby pin in sight.
Using one of my bobby pins, I popped the inside spring and the door sprang open.
“Don’t tell me what to do,” said Isabelle, but after thinking about it she pulled another bobby pin from her pocket.
She walked through the halls with her books pressed against her breasts, in pleated skirt, argyle sweater, white bobby socks folded down crisply above the polished onyx buckles of her shoes.

bourne.description: an archaic term for a boundary
shorts: (noun) an archaic term for a boundary
examples: Or was the vault under the chancel of Gateshead Church an inviting bourne?
If 40 is the landmark birthday from whose bourne no athlete returns, what does that make 30?
And it’s also true that this is a cost that wouldn’t be bourne by US workers, but by foreign ones in part.
By night our ship ran onward toward the Ocean’s bourne, the realm and region of the Men of Winter, hidden in mist and cloud.

shorts: (noun) the center of the Earth
examples: Softening the insertion with the dab of lard, she probed with her middle finger to loosen his bowels.
Morbid curiosity compelled me to peek at the underside of his visible half, which earned me a crystal-clear view of the inner workings of his bowels.
Bran's bowels went to water as the Greatjon struggled to rise, sucking at the red stumps of fingers . . . but then, astonishingly, the huge man laughed.
We all know that the hounds are rewarded with a fouail, or mixture of bowels and bread cooked over a fire, and, of course, poor King Pellinore bad used the wrong word.

brothel.description: a building where prostitutes are available
shorts: (noun) a building where prostitutes are available
examples: Mole's Town came and went, the red lantern over the brothel long extinguished.
“You’d better just hope they don’t think about expanding the brothel, otherwise you’re going to be out of a place to sleep.”
Partly because I needed to and partly for vengeance, I went to the best-known brothel in the city, which had a historic name.
They had crossed the border at Laredo, Texas, the morning of November 23, and spent the first night in a San Luis PotosI brothel.

buxom.description: Buxom is a word that's typically used to describe someone who's full-figured or voluptuous.
shorts: (adjective) (of a female body) healthily plump and vigorous
buxom.long: Although anyone plump and healthy can be buxom, buxom implies having a full chest area. A man can be described as buxom if he has a big barrel chest, but buxom usually describes women. The word buxom used to mean “obedient,” then it meant “cheerful,” and now it’s used just as a physical description.
examples: She was waving her hand like a buxom basketball player.
She enjoyed her new buxom figure but fretted about the consequences.
Under her loose scrutiny I grew more buxom, and my brown skin smoothed and tight-pored, like pancakes fried on an unoiled skillet.
One wants his leg placed so, another so, a third wants water, a fourth wants her to shake his pillow;—in the end the buxom old body grumbled bad-temperedly and slammed the doors.

canteen.description: A canteen is a store that sells food and drink at an institution like a camp, college, or military base. A canteen can also be a small container used to carry water to drink.
shorts: (noun) sells food and personal items to personnel at an institution or school or camp etc.
canteen.long: If you’re at summer camp, you can buy snacks at the canteen. This kind of canteen is a little shop. At the canteen, you can buy little things like potato chips or a can opener. A canteen is like a convenience store. The other kind of canteen is good if you’re going on a hike — fill it up with water and put it in your backpack, since there probably aren’t any of those other kinds of canteens out in the woods.
examples: He nodded and took the canteen from her.
The dinner whistle sounds, and Gale and I line up at the canteen.
Jaime had had the foresight to bring a canteen filled with brandy and we each took a swig to keep our spirits up.
And don’t give yourself away, she said, and drifted back toward the canteen, from where a lot of noise was coming.

shorts: (adverb) with unflagging resolve
examples: People in general prattle ceaselessly about ironies here and ironies there.
Morris was a Lawrence fan who labored ceaselessly to solicit donations for the Rad Lab from his circle of distinguished friends.
I, however, a tropical bird, was cold—cold one way outdoors and cold another way indoors, ceaselessly and more or less thoroughly cold.
It was a bright, whitish silver, and it was moving ceaselessly; the surface of it became ruffled like water beneath wind, and then, like clouds, separated and swirled smoothly.

chloroform.description: a volatile liquid haloform (CHCl3); formerly used as an anesthetic
shorts: (noun) a volatile liquid haloform (CHCl3); formerly used as an anesthetic
(verb) anesthetize with chloroform
examples: ‘They give them one with each meal and the chloroform makes them sleepy and stops them rioting.’
Later, when Holmes returned for more chloroform, Erickson asked him how his experiments were coming.
There was a good deal of macabre testimony about decomposition and body fluids and the effects of chloroform.
He would use chloroform, and she would feel nothing and awaken to the prospect of a new life as Mrs. H. H. Holmes.

claustrophobia.description: Claustrophobia is an irrational or abnormal fear of being in an enclosed space. If your heart races in an elevator, or you break out in a cold sweat in a walk-in closet, you might have claustrophobia.
shorts: (noun) a morbid fear of being closed in a confined space
claustrophobia.long: Claustrophobia is made of ancient Latin words.  Phobia  means "fear," and  claustro  means "bolt" — the kind you put on a door. Broadly speaking, the opposite of claustrophobia is agoraphobia, which is the fear of open spaces. For fun, try adding "-phobia" to your own personal source of dread! For example, “math-phobia.”
examples: Is it claustrophobia, fear of crowds, or common sense?
I didn't say what was creeping up around me—a feeling of claustrophobia.
Someone with claustrophobia is most likely to feel fear in which of the following scenarios?
It induces a kind of psychological claustrophobia that makes one yearn not only for freedom of movement but spiritual escape.

We’ve been hanging out, doing our best to escape the claustrophobia of living behind a guarded electric fence—gabbing, taking circuitous walks around the camp, meeting other kids who have nothing to do.

cleave.description: Cleave, a verb, has two very different meanings. It can describe cutting or splitting something apart with a sharp instrument, or — oddly enough — it can describe sticking to something like glue.
shorts: (verb) separate or cut with a tool, such as a sharp instrument
cleave.long: To cleave or not to cleave, that is the question.  Cleave can refer to being in close contact, to staying really, really close to someone or something: "If you are walking in the pitch-black woods without a flashlight, you want to cleave to the person in front of you."  On the other hand, it can mean to split apart with a sharp tool — which is not the action you want to happen while walking in the woods. We've seen that movie.
examples: The great hemlock bough lay across Gray’s chest, cleaved from the tree.
Every time his blade bit into the ground, he remembered the way it had cleaved into the wolf’s shoulder.
I didn’t realize how much Cara had already cleaved to the idea of being an Allegiant, loyal to the faction system, loyal to our founders.
Sometimes a writer should cleave an intimidating block of print with a paragraph break just to give the reader’s eyes a place to alight and rest.

commissariat.description: a stock or supply of foods
shorts: (noun) a stock or supply of foods
examples: Which of the following is most likely to be described as unstressed?
Jomini defined a commissariat as the coordinating center of an army’s food supply.

As she spoke, she passed a billboard on the side of a local military commissariat building showing Soviet World War II posters and the words: “Everything for the front! Everything to victory! For victory!”

They covered the secretary’s table, the reading desk, the stools—dreary papers of government, still bravely persevered in—of law, still to be codified—of commissariat and of armament and of orders for the day.

"Events of this kind are traditionally held to increase the combat and mobilization readiness of military commissariats, and improve military knowledge and practical skills of those liable for military service," BelTA quoted Krivonosov as saying.

compensation.description: Compensation means "making up for something." When a restaurant offers you a free dessert as compensation for messing up your dinner order, the hope is that you will leave happy (and refrain from writing a negative review online).
shorts: (noun) the act of compensating for service, loss, or injury
compensation.long: Compensation can also be money, a payment meant to give someone a fair exchange for their effort and output. In fact, the word comes from the Latin word compensat-, meaning "weighed against." If you receive fair compensation for your work, the money is equal to your time and effort. In other words, the scale is balanced.
examples: There is no grand compensation to the admission of envy of the poor.
Of course this was long before the compensations for being a girl were apparent to her.
“Regrettably we lack the time to shuttle treasure to you, unless you would reveal Stan’s location before receiving compensation.”
A local legislator introduced a bill seeking compensation on Walter's behalf that prompted the local press to report that Walter was seeking $9 million.

composure.description: When you stay calm under pressure, you keep your composure. Keeping your composure for a skinned knee? Easy. Keeping your composure during an avalanche? Not so easy.
shorts: (noun) steadiness of mind under stress
composure.long: The word composure is from the related word composed, but don't think of the word in the musical sense. In this case, composed means calm. What's the difference between the two? Well, composed is an adjective, so you simply are composed. Composure, on the other hand, is a noun, so you can lose, keep, regain, or maintain your composure — your ability to stay calm. If you lose your composure, you're freaking out.
examples: She had regained her composure; her chin no longer quivered.
Without them I wouldn’t be able to jump back into the fray with my usual composure.
Just a few minutes later, as I was regaining my composure, I noticed the smell of smoke, an acrid odor I couldn’t quite place.
For a long while the girl gazed down at Fossie, almost blankly, and in the candlelight her face had the composure of someone perfectly at peace with herself.

condemnation.description: Condemnation is the act of declaring something awful or evil. If your little brother does something unspeakably awful, express your condemnation so he will learn not to do it again.
shorts: (noun) an expression of strong disapproval; pronouncing as wrong or morally culpable
condemnation.long: Condemnation comes from the verb condemn, "to strongly disapprove." You might criticize something that you still think is worthwhile, but if you express condemnation, that’s laying a heavy moral blame. Condemnation is used in law, and means the same thing as sentencing; you might have heard a judge say “I condemn you to ten years of hard labor.” Also, a very dangerous building will be sealed up and deemed uninhabitable by an act of condemnation.
examples: He seemed to take offense at some condemnation he heard in my tone.
Which of the following would most likely be considered an expression of condemnation?
Her voice held all the shock and condemnation of the small town, I thought critically.
His condemnation was severe and wide-ranging, while his praise seemed like a grudging afterthought: Hundreds of blacks had come to their white neighbors’ aid, so why not say so?

Instead, he remained offstage, leaving the campaign of condemnation to Karl Compton, who was serving as scientific advisor to the occupation forces and publicly labeled the cyclotron destruction “an act of utter stupidity.”

confound.description: If you have an identical twin, you've probably tried dressing alike so that people confound you with, or mistake you for, one another. You've also probably learned that, unfortunately, this trick doesn’t work on your mom.
shorts: (verb) be confusing or perplexing to; cause to be unable to think clearly
confound.long: The verb confound means both "to mistake" and "to confuse." If you decide to treat yourself to a delicious dessert, you might find yourself confounded by the overwhelming number of choices. If you end up ordering the chocolate cake but the waiter brings you chocolate mousse, the waiter has somehow confounded those two options. Another meaning you may come across in literature is "to damn," as in "Confound it! You are the most exasperating person on the planet."
examples: He had confounded them all by passing the test, although they still refused him the ballot .
Sometimes correlated quantities are causally related, but other “confounding” factors complicate and obscure the causal relations.
It's fine to cure the leukemia sufferers but much more satisfying to imagine the parade of opportunists confounded by my refusal to cooperate.
No wonder Atticus confounded Henry in the early days of their association by saying, “Pleading’s little more than putting on paper what you want to say.”

congeal.description: Congeal means to jell — to solidify or become gelatinous. Sounds gross? But wiggly Jell-O is actually congealed liquid, so it can't be that bad, right?
shorts: (verb) become gelatinous
congeal.long: This word comes to us from the Old French word congeler, which means "to freeze." So when something congeals it goes from liquid to solid form, almost like freezing. No one usually likes congealed anything — whether it's chunkified old soup in the fridge or dried blood on a wound. See? Pretty gross. Jell-O is about as good as congealed gets!
examples: I don’t like spaghetti when it’s normal, let alone congealed.
There were dead bodies everywhere and flies were feasting on the congealed blood on them.
The gruel was grey and watery, and he pushed it away after his third spoonful and let it congeal in the bowl.
The first few times I saw her, I kept my distance—but right now, that feeling of being a chunk of pineapple congealed in Jell-O isn’t as strong as other times.

convalescent.description: A person who's recovering from an illness is a convalescent. As a convalescent recovering from surgery, your grandmother would probably love some company to cheer her and help pass the time.
shorts: (adjective) returning to health after illness or debility
(noun) a person who is recovering from illness
convalescent.long: Convalescent, as an adjective, can describe the period of recovery or anything related to the process of returning to health, like a convalescent program of physical therapy or a convalescent ward at a hospital. As a noun, a convalescent is a person who is recovering from being sick. The origin of convalescent is the Latin root valescere, which means "to begin to grow strong."
examples: For that reason we did not spend a convalescent leave together.
The convalescent leave started October fourth when my course was finished.
The Albemarle had been built in the nineteenth century, as a retreat for rich convalescents.

“Unless you find something else I’m afraid you will have to go back to the front when you are through with your jaundice. I don’t believe self-inflicted jaundice entitles you to a convalescent leave.”

convulse.description: To convulse is to have spasms. Get help immediately if you see someone convulse. This medical condition can be brought on by something simple (like a rise in body temperature) or something more complicated, such as epilepsy.
shorts: (verb) move or stir about violently
convulse.long: In addition to being a symptom of a medical condition, to convulse is often applied to people shaking with laughter. So if you go to a club and see a hilarious comedian, you may convulse with laughter so hard that you might cry, or not be able to catch your breath, and your sides hurt.
examples: And he stuck his big, ugly tongue out and pretended to convulse.
Dimple moved her arms around and hoped to God she didn’t look like she was convulsing.
The albino fairy pulled the convulsing catfish from the aquarium and changed her back into Lena.
Mrs. Coulter’s right hand had convulsed so tightly that it clung to the mesh, leaving her half-lying, half-hanging, while her head rang and her heart pounded.

cunning.description: In fairy tales, always watch out for the cunning fox or the cunning witch. Cunning means clever, in the sense of trickery. A cunning plan might involve setting traps for the innocent and pure at heart to fall into.
shorts: (adjective) showing inventiveness and skill
(noun) crafty artfulness (especially in deception)
cunning.long: This adjective goes back to the 14th-century English verb cunnen, which meant "to know," and is actually related to our English verb know. In earlier times, the noun was used to mean a high level of skill in using the hands. You can be cunning, but you can also use your cunning to figure out a very clever and tricky plan.
examples: “Ah, man’s cunning mind!” he said, and cackled.
He is clever and cunning and resourceful; but he be not of man-stature as to brain.
Polly was known to be a cunning dog and could get Charles to give her what she wanted.
From up here, it felt like looking out over a fantasy world, a world wrought by Dwarvish cunning and Elven magic.

debauch.description: Debauch means to destroy or corrupt someone's morals. Overnight fame and wealth might debauch a previously mild-mannered and altruistic actor. As a noun, debauch refers to a wild party characterized by excess.
shorts: (noun) a wild gathering
(verb) corrupt morally or by intemperance or sensuality
debauch.long: The old-fashioned meaning of debauch involved antiquated ideas about virtue and the idea that a person's "moral purity" could be corrupted. Today this word is mostly used when a person's integrity or principles are corrupted, often under the influence of money or power. You might say that artists debauch themselves when their designs show up on mass produced T-shirts. As a noun, debauch refers to an out-of-control party — in other words, a gathering at which one's morals might be corrupted.
examples: Some of the Folk are so still I worry that they have debauched themselves into death.
Horrible, debauched, mouth limp and cracked, loose against the teeth as an ancient dog’s.
There are others that seem to be about assignations, about revels and parties and debauches.
“You are meant to be working separately, not in this...this debauched juxtaposition. I have warned you about collaborating, it is not the proper way to exhibit your skills.”

delirium.description: Experiencing delirium? Then you're out of your mind and so excited you're hallucinating. Many things can cause delirium, including illness, high stress, and your team winning the World Series after 100 years of trying.
shorts: (noun) a usually brief state of excitement and mental confusion often accompanied by hallucinations
delirium.long: Delirium means “madness” in Latin, and for good reason. Patients with high fevers or who suffer severe trauma might experience a state of delirium, full of mental confusion and maybe a little hysteria. And if you’ve ever stayed up all night writing a paper or working hard to meet some deadline, you’ve probably experienced moments of delirium, where you feel crazed and hallucinatory, fueled by sleep deprivation and too much coffee.
examples: Sense would resist delirium: judgment would warn passion.
While Cora twisted in her delirium, Ethel read from the Bible to speed her recuperation.
Celia pieces together his story from the torments he relives in delirium, between fevers and chills and a painful catarrh.
At first he called only for help—the second night he must have had some delirium, he talked with his wife and his children, we often detected the name Elise.

shorts: (verb) free of lice
examples: Where, among these below, would you most likely gain a vantage?
Billy went from total dark to total light, found himself back in the war, back in the delousing station again.
Then they ran me through a kind of human car wash—a series of machines that soaped, scrubbed, disinfected, rinsed, dried, and deloused me.
Once Mr. Bow spotted the lice, he escorted me to a delousing shower room in the hospital and I washed with a parasiticide that smelled like licorice.

Now that Americans have mostly deloused themselves, typhus has discovered a new route into us: by infecting eastern North American flying squirrels and then transferring to people whose attics harbor flying squirrels.

demolish.description: Demolish means “completely destroy,” as a wrecking ball might demolish a building, or as hanging out with one’s parents might, supposedly, demolish a teenager’s reputation.
shorts: (verb) destroy completely
demolish.long: In casual speech, demolish can also mean “devour,” as a group of hungry teenagers might demolish a pizza. The noun form of demolish is demolition, which often implies destruction by means of explosives. Demolish combines the prefix de-, which can mean “undo,” with the Latin verb moliri, meaning “to build" — which makes sense if you are thinking of 'undoing a building' with explosives!
examples: I pace along the sidewalk, away from the demolished school.
Mr. Go much prefers to sit in the Show Room, in the stained Art Deco theater seats that originally belonged to a movie house in Oakland, now demolished.
Sometimes this was manifested as a new willingness to admit error, as when Niels Bohr visited Berkeley in April 1937 and casually demolished an Oppenheimer theory based on results from the cyclotron.

Unfortunately, his success in demolishing the supposed antipathy between garlic and magnets remained hidden from history until very recently; it is della Porta who established the new fact within the world of learning, not Garzoni.

derive.description: If you want to talk about something that comes from something else, but you want to sound sophisticated and maybe financial or scientific, use derive, like so: That scent? It's derived from a solution of roses boiled with toothpicks.
shorts: (verb) come from
derive.long: The word derive derives from (see how we did that?) the Latin rivus or stream, as in water. That image of the stream may help you remember the meaning of derive; you may picture tracing tiny streams back to their main source. Derive is a verb, as you can see, but it's often in the news in the noun form derivative: something that is derived from something else, as in "juice is a derivative of an orange."
examples: Logograms for abstract words were often derived by the rebus principle.
Modern pigs are derived from independent sequences of domestication in China, western Eurasia, and possibly other areas as well.
After a while he fell asleep, and she lay there holding his head, deriving a small but important comfort, even faintly smiling as she stared at the ceiling.
To approach the question about the Bantu’s advantages, let’s examine the remaining type of evidence from the living present—the evidence derived from domesticated plants and animals.

despicable.description: Stealing the last piece of food from a starving child goes way beyond mean. It's despicable — a vile and harmful act.
shorts: (adjective) morally reprehensible
despicable.long: Mean, nasty, and scummy are synonyms of despicable, but they don't fully convey the awfulness of despicable. A man who lies to get a promotion meant for his co-worker would be considered mean. But the despicable man — the one who is so awful and worthless that he deserves to be despised — is the one who burns down the office building and frames his co-worker for it.
examples: If I held them out to save Peeta because I knew I would be shunned if I came back without him, then I am despicable.
According to the rumor, there is someone out there who is seeking out corrupt, despicable scythes...and ending their existence by fire.
So that if in the future she ever fell from grace, it would be understood that presidents—even the most despicable—get special treatment.
He is the sort of despicable person who has no understanding of how despicable he is, and my badgering him with insults won’t change that; nothing will.

destitute.description: When you think of the word destitute, which means poor or lacking other necessities of life, think of someone who is in desperate straits. A very, very tight budget is poor. Living on the streets is destitute.
shorts: (adjective) poor enough to need help from others
destitute.long: Destitute essentially means not having something. When you're destitute in the sense of being poor, you're technically "destitute of money." You can be destitute of other things as well. If all your friends have abandoned you, you're "destitute of friends." If you are applying for a job as a waitress but have never worked in a restaurant in any capacity, you're "destitute of experience."
examples: The Fowls were not left destitute, far from it.
And if little or none of that money filtered down to the destitute farmers of the Miracle Valley, well—when had it ever?
“You are very kind, I am sure; and I wish with all my heart it may prove so, for else they will be destitute enough. Things are settled so oddly.”
The Slabs functions as the seasonal capital of a teeming itinerant society—a tolerant, rubber-tired culture comprising the retired, the exiled, the destitute, the perpetually unemployed.

devastation.description: When there's devastation, there's terrible destruction. You can see the devastation from a violent hurricane and feel devastation over all the people that were injured.
shorts: (noun) the state of being decayed or destroyed
devastation.long: When a natural disaster causes widespread death and destruction, that's devastation. This is a strong word that suggests serious damage has occurred, leaving almost nothing left. One knocked over car isn't devastation, but a whole town being wiped out is. People can also feel devastation — it's a kind of extreme sadness or state of feeling emotionally wrecked.
examples: But I couldn’t let my own devastation show.
And yet when it came to the election none of the devastation seemed to matter.
Dad calls her Hurricane Gloria because he says she leaves a trail of devastation in her wake.
They saw the images of devastation and desperation, and could not believe that their uncle was living amid all that.

devour.description: When you've gone all day without eating anything, you'll probably devour your dinner, especially if it's your very favorite homemade lasagna. Devour means to eat greedily and hungrily.
shorts: (verb) eat immoderately
devour.long: The meaning of devour has grown to include the consumption of things other than food. If you sit down to start a book and look up ten hours later having turned the last page, you have devoured that book. If your after school job devours all your free time, chances are your grades are going to drop. The Latin root, devorare, means "to swallow down."
examples: The mob devoured all the food in the clubhouse.
Like most kings, he was a god who only ever devoured.
When the victim stops walking and sinks to their knees to weep at the pointlessness of it all, the Pogrebin will leap upon them and attempt to devour them.
I think my mom might have been pretty once, but the years devoured her youth, beauty, and enthusiasm for anything with an alcohol content of less than 12 percent.

differentiate.description: To differentiate is to identify the differences between things, to discriminate among them. For example, if the light is dim at the party, you might find it hard to differentiate between the spicy bean dip and the chocolate sauce.
shorts: (verb) become distinct and acquire a different character
differentiate.long: You can see different in differentiate. This will help you remember that it has to do with finding how things are different, or making them different. For example, identical twins look alike but if you get to know them, personality traits, speech patterns and their likes and dislikes help differentiate one from another. Also, when you wear a team uniform the number on your back helps coaches differentiate between teammates when everyone is playing fast.
examples: All white people looked similar to Negroes but Negroes took care to differentiate between them.
Barnsley argues that these kinds of skewed age distributions exist whenever three things happen: selection, streaming, and differentiated experience.
It was called that to differentiate it from a celluloid collar which was what poor men wore because it could be laundered simply by being wiped with a wet rag.

He felt himself included once again in the circle of humanity and was expecting from both the doctor and the locksmith, without differentiating between them with any real precision, splendid and surprising results.

disconcert.description: To disconcert is to unsettle someone, or make them feel confused and out of sorts. Finding a soup ladle in your sock drawer would definitely disconcert you!
shorts: (verb) cause to lose one's composure
disconcert.long: Disconcert comes from the old French word disconcerter, meaning "confused."  The prefix dis means "not" — it has a bad attitude and shows up in words like disagree and disown. The second part of the word comes from the verb concerter, "to bring together." If you disconcert someone, you make them feel uncomfortable and maybe a little embarrassed.
examples: Though baffled, I was not a bit disconcerted.
“I... I don’t follow you,” Chronicler said, disconcerted.
The effect was disconcerting, dizzying; her too-tight beaded slippers seemed to float in midair.
There was a disconcerting gleam in his eye, as if he wanted to have a bite of her rather than the biscuit.

disgruntle.description: put into a bad mood or into bad humour
shorts: (verb) put into a bad mood or into bad humour
examples: Which of the following is sedimentary?
Effie Trinket is disgruntled about the state her wig was in.
Taro makes a noise like a disgruntled cow, and then he looks at me.
One of my disgruntled neighbors had the audacity to say, “If you love black people so much, why don’t you just marry a monkey?”
And yet a pernicious seed had been planted—a perception of me as disgruntled and vaguely hostile, lacking some expected level of grace.

divination.description: The idea that you can see the future by supernatural means is called divination. When your friend tells your fortune by reading the tea leaves in your cup, she claims to have the power of divination.
shorts: (noun) the art or gift of prophecy (or the pretense of prophecy) by supernatural means
divination.long: The prediction or prophecy itself that's given through the act of fortune telling is also called divination. A psychic's divination that your aunt will soon start a family is much less impressive if your aunt is obviously pregnant. You can also use divination to refer to someone's unusual intuition, like a child who seems to know by divination when someone is feeling sad or upset.
examples: Then you sort through the results and determine the divination.
As was customary, high priests subjected this choice to a divination.
She seemed to be weighing whether to go on, as if deciding if I was worthy of receiving her divination.
At the bottom, wrapped in a silk scarf, was a book she’d had for twenty years: a commentary on the Chinese method of divination, the I Ching.

downy.description: Things that are downy are very soft and fluffy. Babies are sometimes born with little tufts of downy hair on their heads.
shorts: (adjective) like down or as soft as down
downy.long: A teenage boy who wants to grow a beard will be frustrated by the downy hairs on his chin, and you could also describe the feeling of a peach as downy. When you rip your winter coat, the downy feathers inside might start floating out behind you in a trail wherever you go. These are also known as down, or the soft feathers that typically grow on a young bird — this is the origin, in fact, of downy.
examples: In his palm chirps a downy yellow fuzz, just hatched.
“I wish that were true,” said Sam, stroking the downy head.
Sumac was asleep on my shoulder, his head turned around so his beak rested in the downy softness of his back.
Yossarian was stunned at how waxen and ghastly Snowden’s bare leg looked, how loathsome, how lifeless and esoteric the downy, fine, curled blond hairs on his odd, white shin and calf.

dysentery.description: Dysentery is a nasty sounding word for a nasty condition: an intestinal infection that results in diarrhea.
shorts: (noun) an infection of the intestines marked by severe diarrhea
dysentery.long: There are few things as unpleasant as dysentery, an infectious condition, kind of like the flu, that includes severe diarrhea. Dysentery is common in countries and places with poor health conditions and sewage problems. If the drinking water is filthy, that's a great way to spread dysentery. This word sounds kind of dirty, and that's a good hint to its meaning: the horrible illness of dysentery spreads in dirty, unsafe living conditions.
examples: Which of the following could be best described as viviparous?
When the Mexicans were joined by their ally, dysentery, it was godawful.
The factory owners in Germany have grown wealthy;—dysentery dissolves our bowels.
There were outbreaks of camp fever, smallpox, and dysentery amongst the rebel troops.
“It’s dysentery—which could be contagious, so we shouldn’t eat anything you’ve touched. I’m sorry.”

emaciate.description: To emaciate is to make someone extremely thin or very weak. A serious illness can often emaciate a person, leaving them gaunt and frail.
shorts: (verb) grow weak and thin or waste away physically
emaciate.long: The verb emaciate is much less common than its related adjective, emaciated. Both stem from the Latin emaciare, "make lean, cause to waste away." Whenever a person has become malnourished in a way that's evident just from looking at them, you can use this word: "The ravages of the Irish potato famine emaciated the starving people all across the country, eventually causing a million deaths."
examples: For an emaciated ghoul, Akhlys could run pretty fast when she wanted to.
“We were filthy, our camp uniforms almost rotted off our bodies, and both of us so weak and emaciated, we could hardly stand,” Jack said.
Following my example, Tommy and Ruth made their way to another tree trunk, hollow and more emaciated than mine, a short way behind to my left.
At their head was a man stick-thin and very tall, with a drawn emaciated face made even longer by the ropy black beard that grew from his pointed chin nearly to his waist.

entanglement.description: an intricate trap that entangles or ensnares its victim
shorts: (noun) an intricate trap that entangles or ensnares its victim
examples: She descended from her roost, numb in her arms and legs from her entanglement in the rough limbs.
Everywhere wire-cutters are snapping, planks are thrown across the entanglements, we jump through the narrow entrances into the trenches.
“Like, the smaller things get, the crazier science becomes. When you start talking about p-branes and quantum immortality and entanglement...Well, it’s just cool is all.”
Since they don’t have any kind of survival instinct it’s no big deal for them to eventually pull themselves free of such an entanglement, ripping off great big swatches of themselves to do so.

esprit de corps.description: When a group — whether it's a team, club, class, or Scout troop — gives its members a sense of cohesion and support, it has esprit de corps.
shorts: (noun) the spirit of a group that makes the members want the group to succeed
esprit de corps.long: If you've ever been on a sports team that had great morale and team spirit, you've experienced esprit de corps. The term is French, and it literally means "the spirit of the body," with body in this case meaning "group." Originally, esprit de corps was used to describe the morale of military troops. Pronounce it with a hint of a French accent: "espree de core."
examples: “You can tell this isn’t a Marine base. There's no spirit here. No esprit de corps.”
Momma, you would not believe the camaraderie and esprit de corps in these hallowed halls.
Mutual assistance is a theme, and the Ailey dancers convincingly applied their esprit de corps.
In 1928, when I was nine, I belonged, with maximum esprit de corps, to an organization known as the Comanche Club.

evacuate.description: To evacuate is to flee, like how people leave an area when a hurricane is coming. It also means to empty something completely.
shorts: (verb) move out of an unsafe location into safety
evacuate.long: If you have to evacuate your home, something horrible is probably happening, like a natural disaster. People evacuate when something like a tornado or act of terrorism makes their homes unsafe. To evacuate also means to empty completely, in the bathroom-oriented sense of evacuating (emptying) your bowels. Similarly, if a chemist empties and therefore creates a vacuum in a flask, she has evacuated the flask. When you evacuate, you clear out.
examples: The boy said it came from a doctor in Stanleyville who was being evacuated.
“We evacuated this area almost two weeks ago. Where’ve you been, you don’t know that?”
Zeitoun’s earlier assumption—that they were being evacuated by force—seemed to be confirmed.
The general manager sympathized with Dalgard and agreed with him that the monkey facility ought to be evacuated and shut down.

expound.description: If your grandmother's handwritten pie recipe calls for "some sugar," "plenty of butter," and "sliced apples," you might ask her to expound by adding measurements of how much of each to use. When you expound, you explain or provide details.
shorts: (verb) add details, as to an account or idea; clarify the meaning of and discourse in a learned way, usually in writing
expound.long: Expound came into English from a 14th-century French word espondre meaning "to elaborate" or "put forth." Often when you expound something you are clarifying or giving the particulars. A more formal way to expound is to offer exposition, often going line by line to explain precise meanings in a text or legal document.
examples: He never expounds on education theory or education reform.
The allegation, which was untrue, irritated the detectives into expounding very convincing denials.
Several nights a week, after Mr. Jones was asleep, they held secret meetings in the barn and expounded the principles of Animalism to the others.

He wrote and telephoned dozens of acceptances to invitations to speak, predominantly at colleges and universities—both to expound his philosophies and to earn the $150-$300 honorariums above traveling expenses.

fastidious.description: If you want to describe a person who insists on perfection or pays much attention to food, clothing and cleanliness, the right word is fastidious.
shorts: (adjective) giving careful attention to detail; hard to please; excessively concerned with cleanliness
fastidious.long: Fastidious is a funny-sounding adjective from the Latin fastidium "loathing" that has several equally strange-sounding synonyms — persnickety, fussbudgety, finicky and punctilious. Fussy and hard to please will also do the trick. Fastidious is occasionally used as a compliment to describe someone whose attention to detail gives them good organizing abilities, but it is usually used as a disapproving term.
examples: “My sister Beth is a very fastidious girl, when she likes to be,” said Amy, well pleased at Beth’s success.
She meant ‘facinating’, but as Grace didn’t know the exact meaning of either word, fastidious sounded well and made a good impression.
A fastidious dresser stuck in a small, unfashionable town, Mister Mancini wore clothing I recognized from the Young Squires department of Hudson Belk.

Our shared room resembled an ideological battlefield, with Suzanne presiding over a wrecked landscape of tossed clothing and strewn papers on her side and me perched on my bed, surrounded by fastidious order.

Prairie dogs are not ________ in their choice of companions; various long, checkered snakes were sunning themselves in the midst of the village, and demure little gray owls, with a large white ring around each eye, were perched side by side with the rightful inhabitants.

fortnight.description: A fortnight is fourteen nights, or two weeks. This word isn't used much in American English, but you'll come across it if you travel to England — or read a lot of old British novels.
shorts: (noun) a period of fourteen consecutive days
fortnight.long: The word fortnight is still in use in Great Britain and some former British colonies. It comes from the Old English, and is literally a shortened form of fourteen nights. People sometimes use it when they're discussing their vacations or their pay schedules. In the United States, however, people typically just say "two weeks."
examples: About a fortnight later she was able to sit out in the garden.
Prince Rhaegar was returning from Dome, and he and his escort had lingered here a fortnight.
When nearly a fortnight had passed Frodo looked out of his window and saw that there had been a frost in the night, and the cobwebs were like white nets.
‘Of course not. But never mind. You can see me on my way. Tell Rose that you won’t be away very long, not more than a fortnight; and you’ll come back quite safe.’

gangrene.description: You don't want gangrene, that's for sure. It's the infection that can develop around a wound that kills the tissue, turning it into a terrible stinking sore.
shorts: (noun) the localized death of living cells (as from infection or the interruption of blood supply)
(verb) undergo necrosis
gangrene.long: In the days before antibiotics even the smallest scratch could lead to gangrene, and doctors would often cut off a finger or even a limb and then seal it with a red hot poker rather than risk the infection spreading. Special surgeons known as sawbones were famed for the speed they could amputate a limb to avoid gangrene setting in. Enough to stop you ever being nostalgic about the good old days.
examples: “You are supposed to be in bed, dying of gangrene or something.”
Roland Weary died—of gangrene that had started in his mangled feet.
It has a nasty, mean disposition and its teeth are green with gangrene and it bites.
If I can’t quite get the hang of poverty-chastity-and-obedience, I can learn instead about vermifuges, breech deliveries, arrow wounds, gangrene, and elephantiasis.

generation.description: A generation can refer to a group of people who live at the same time and are about the same age. But generation is also the act of creating something, such as income, ideas or kids.
shorts: (noun) group of genetically related organisms constituting a single step in the line of descent
generation.long: In 1965, Pete Townsend, the guitarist of The Who, wrote a song called "My Generation." The Who, Jefferson Airplane, Jimi Hendrix and other popular musicians of the day were called “the Woodstock Generation,” because they performed at a famous music festival in Woodstock, New York.  Generation is used in another way when people credit those bands — along with Elvis, the Beatles and the Rolling Stones — with the generation of rock-and-roll culture.
examples: But who, if not me, and for how many generations must we be forgiven by our children?
And this view of things was connected to the fear that passed through the generations, to the sense of dispossession.
There were only a dangerous forest and a single road and a thin grip on a life that the Elders had enjoyed for generations.
Her mother, Ann, was a Powell, another educated, upwardly mobile colored family—and the same Powells who would two generations later produce Colin Powell.

glower.description: If you see someone glower at you, you might consider glowering back, but no one likes an angry staring contest. To glower is not only to stare, it's to stare angrily, as if you're going to throttle someone.
shorts: (verb) look angry or sullen, wrinkle one's forehead, as if to signal disapproval
(noun) an angry stare
glower.long: You might already have guessed that glower isn't of Greek or Latin origin, since it doesn't ring any of those bells. Chances are that glower comes from northern Europe, where it's related to some old words that mean to "glow." It was probably in the 18th century that it took on the meaning "stare at angrily or sullenly." You can use its root, glo, to recall its meaning: a person that glowers seems to glow with anger.
examples: I know Dad is trying to point out the bright side, but I glower.
When I flinched from the glare of a bracelet, the guard in front glowered at me even harder.
After five minutes, Pauline twitched her thumb, and the cello woman was replaced by an Ansel Adams landscape, Mount McKinley glowering over a lake of pure white.
“Because then mine will be angry with me for making her work for her money,” Nately replied with an anxious look at his girl, who was glowering at him restlessly and starting to mutter.

gnaw.description: To gnaw is to bite or chew. Your favorite food might be corn on the cob, because you love to gnaw along each row of kernels.
shorts: (verb) bite or chew on with the teeth
gnaw.long: To gnaw also means to deteriorate or wear away as if by gnawing with the teeth. In Arches National Park, the weather has gnawed away at the rocks creating beautiful formations like arches, bridges, and balanced rocks. In this sense, to gnaw can be used even more figuratively. Something might gnaw at the back of your mind — something you were supposed to do, although now you can't quite remember what it was.
examples: She gnawed like a rat into the godown of Chacko’s grief.
I craned into the open air, had my teeth around the plant fiber, and was about to start gnawing when voices made me freeze.
As he walked toward the East Door, he couldn’t stop picturing Winston in a dark corner of the barn, gnawing on raw pigs’ feet.
Broken shingles from the roof covered the floor, there was an empty sack in a corner, some broken earthenware shards, perhaps from a dish or a plate, and a few bones gnawed clean.

grievous.description: If something is called grievous, you better take it seriously. Grievous is used to describe horrible things like tragedies or crimes. If you have a grievous wound, a band aid simply won't do.
shorts: (adjective) causing or marked by grief or anguish
grievous.long: Grievous is derived from the noun grief, which means "sadness." When something is grievous, therefore, it's not just bad, but so bad that it causes unusually intense shock or sadness. It's often used to describe crimes and other bad deeds that go beyond mere criminality and into the world of cruelty. For example, it's harmful to steal from someone; it's grievous to steal from them and then, having stolen their stuff, beat them up or kill them.
examples: "I fear so, my lord. It is so sad. So grievous sad. And them so young and innocent."
“Poor boy,” she said, with a pitying smile, “there has been grievous mischief done today.”
‘These are evil tidings,’ said Celeborn, ‘the most evil that have been spoken here in long years full of grievous deeds.’
Then it seemed to Gimli and Legolas who were nearby that she wept, and in one so stern and proud that seemed the more grievous.

grub.description: The noun grub can refer either to a soft, young insect or to hearty food. If your best friend invites you over for some grub, don't worry — she almost certainly means the food and not the bugs.
shorts: (noun) a soft thick wormlike larva of certain beetles and other insects
(verb) ask for and get free; be a parasite
grub.long: The grubs your dad picks off of his tomato plant are insects, while the grub you eat in the school cafeteria includes spaghetti and Sloppy Joes. The most interesting thing about this word is how it went from describing a squishy, arguably gross little beetle larva to an informal term for something delicious. Experts guess that it comes from birds gobbling grubs. This slang definition has been around since the 17th century.
examples: “The chief mate don’t settle for less than the finest grub.”
Plug is self-sufficient; after a handful of oats, he is turned out to find his own grub.
Nuremberg society, like that of Frankfurt, would frown on a married woman gathering grubs and caterpillars.
I’m goin’ to get you some quilts and things from Nancy’s place; I’ll bring you what grub I can lay hands on—I can always get eggs and a chicken for you.

hemorrhage.description: Medically speaking, a hemorrhage is a rapid loss of blood. If you fall and hit your head really hard, the doctors will check to see there's no cerebral hemorrhage, or bleeding in your brain.
shorts: (noun) the flow of blood from a ruptured blood vessel
(verb) lose blood from one's body
hemorrhage.long: Hemorrhage is pronounced HEM-or-edge. Blame the Greeks for the funny spelling, because like many medical terms, this one comes from Greek roots. Besides the medical meaning, we use hemorrhage to mean the uncontrollable loss of other things. If sudden disaster is making you hemorrhage money, you'll have to cut back on fancy dinners and new shoes. Can I recommend frozen pizza?
examples: The skin develops red spots, called petechiae, which are hemorrhages under the skin.
Her eighth child, Leopold, had inherited the gene and died of a brain hemorrhage at age thirty.
It was Ebola blood, and it had run everywhere inside the animal: there had been a lot of internal hemorrhaging.
Your heart bleeds into itself; the heart muscle softens and has hemorrhages into its chambers, and blood squeezes out of the heart muscle as the heart beats, and it floods the chest cavity.

impinge.description: Whether you have a habit of standing too close when talking to others or bringing luggage on a crowded rush-hour subway car, you'll find people don't like it when you impinge on their personal space.
shorts: (verb) impinge or infringe upon
impinge.long: When you impinge, you intrude on something, whether it’s someone else’s space, time, or rights. Think of it as moving in on someone’s territory. The word also can be used in the sense of affecting something, usually negatively, often by restricting it. For example, constantly inviting your friend to go shopping and meet you in nice restaurants might impinge on her desire to save money.
examples: It showed that a person’s decision making is impinged by something as simple as a modest memory task.
State legislators did not look kindly on government regulations they felt would impinge on personal freedoms.
All that business about “unzipping,” that was typical of the way the whole subject impinged on us when we were thirteen.
According to atomists such as Gassendi, light was caused by a stream of tiny particles emerging from bright objects, like the Sun, and impinging on the eyes of the viewer.

indigent.description: An indigent person is extremely poor, lacking the basic resources of a normal life. Often the indigent lack not only money but homes.
shorts: (adjective) poor enough to need help from others
indigent.long: Indigent comes from a Latin word meaning wanting, which we used to use to mean “lacking” and not just to describe desires. Homeless shelters, soup kitchens, free medical clinics and court-appointed lawyers are all institutions that our society has developed to help indigent people.
examples: Approximately 80 percent of criminal defendants are indigent and thus unable to hire a lawyer.
Telemarketing, one of the first refuges of the suddenly indigent, can be dismissed on grounds of personality.
The bodies of the indigent dead were carted to the potter’s field and dumped, but no gravediggers were there to bury them.
Civil rights groups have also developed litigation and important coalitions related to the school-to-prison pipeline, inadequate indigent defense, and juvenile justice reform, to name a few.

inducement.description: The act of persuading someone to do something is called inducement. If you're training a dog, you might use food as an inducement to make the dog do what you want. This works with some humans too.
shorts: (noun) a positive motivational influence
inducement.long: The original meaning of the noun inducement came from the Latin verb inducere, meaning "to lead or persuade."  Roman philosopher Seneca said, “There is no evil that does not promise inducements. Avarice promises money; luxury, a varied assortment of pleasures; ambition, a purple robe and applause. Vices tempt you by the rewards they offer.”  So you can be seduced to bad behavior by some inducements or encouraged to good behavior by others.  Would you like a treat?
examples: “I hope I shall. I have many inducements to do so.”
“He is, indeed—but, considering the inducement, my dear Miss Eliza, we cannot wonder at his complaisance; for who would object to such a partner?”
I was to write Washington that a major inducement in my wanting to be in Cambridge was the presence of Roy Markham, an English biochemist who worked with plant viruses.
Many educators believe that the Race to the Top, with its strictly defined inducements and penalties, will do even more to constrict curriculums than No Child Left Behind.

infuriate.description: Different things infuriate different people: whatever makes you angry, mad, or ticked off infuriates you.
shorts: (verb) make furious
infuriate.long: Fury is a word for "anger" that should help with this word: to infuriate is to fill someone with fury, i.e., anger. Unless you're new to the planet, you've probably noticed many things that are infuriating: people talking too loudly on their phones, the cancellation of your favorite TV show, stepping in a puddle, someone stealing from you, stubbing your toe. These annoying events could infuriate anyone. Sometimes you might infuriate someone else by accident. Like it or not, we all infuriate someone sometime.
examples: One of the things which makes this so infuriating is that the system favors shallow people.
He’s particularly infuriating on Sundays, when he switches on the light at the crack of dawn to exercise for ten minutes.
It’s infuriating that despite her extended absence, my big sister can still read me like the Dr. Seuss books she used to recite at bedtime.
It was infuriating to find herself behind in almost every subject, but she knew that the fault lay in Hollywood Gardens Elementary and not in herself.

insensate.description: Insensate is a word to describe something without feelings or consciousness. Cars, computers, and stuffed animals are all insensate (though some of us occasionally project thoughts and personalities onto them).
shorts: (adjective) devoid of feeling and consciousness and animation
insensate.long: Insensate can also describe individuals who seem to lack the characteristically human emotions of kindness and generosity. A person who tears a stuffed animal out of the hands of a young child might be described as insensate. Another meaning of insensate is “lacking intelligence.” In short, insensate, in any sense of the word, is usually something that you don’t want to be.
examples: She crawls to an edge inside herself, longs to be insensate, a slab of brick.
At the field a heavy silence prevailed, overpowering motion like a ruthless, insensate spell holding in thrall the only beings who might break it.
Jocko’s head lolled, and I could not but recall that awful vision, the insensate head of the dead sniper upon the stairs, cheek pierced by our musket-fire.
Summer of 1918—Breath of hope that sweeps over the scorched fields, raging fever of impatience, of disappointment, of the most agonizing terror of death, insensate question: Why?

insubordination.description: People in charge — like bosses and teachers — hate insubordination, which means that someone is defying their authority.
shorts: (noun) defiance of authority
insubordination.long: When a student is disrespectful to a teacher or says something like "I won't do this homework!", that's an act of insubordination. If a teacher didn't do what the principal wanted, that would also be insubordination. This word is often used in relation to the military, where giving and taking orders is extremely important. A soldier who commits insubordination — by disobeying an order — can be in a lot of trouble. Anywhere there's insubordination, someone with less power (a subordinate) is giving someone with more power a whole lot of trouble.
examples: The captain’s eyeball fixes on Carlyle, burning at the insubordination—a lowly swabby second-guessing his order.
“Incompetence over Ferrara, insubordination, refusal to engage the enemy in combat when ordered to do so, and desertion.”
I sit in the car on the long ride back trying to keep rage alive by rehearsing what I’ll say when Ted fires me for insubordination.
Sam had a way to respond to people who called him Chief—as long as they weren’t superior officers who could bust him for insubordination.

irresolute.description: Irresolute describes someone who feels stuck. A decision must be made, a plan acted on, but the irresolute person just doesn't know what to do.
shorts: (adjective) uncertain how to act or proceed
irresolute.long: Resolute describes certainty. When someone is resolute, things get done: plans are made and carried out. But add the prefix ir to resolute and you get its opposite. An irresolute person isn't necessarily a slacker — he or she just doesn't know what to do. Maybe it's confusion. Maybe it's a matter of waiting for better information to come along. Either way, if someone is irresolute, you'll need to be patient — or willing to nudge him or her into action.
examples: For an indefinite time I remain completely irresolute.
He stepped forward; but Boromir stood irresolute and did not follow.
In order to avoid present dangers, irresolute princes follow the neutral path most of the time, and most of the time they come to ruin.
I knew that every minute was precious to me, yet I remained ________ in what manner to commence the interview, when the old man addressed me.
He stood irresolute, making some excuse about his mother who expected him; he even muttered something about an engagement She struck a match and lit the lamp on the table; it was growing dusk.

knapsack.description: A knapsack is a bag with two straps that you wear over your shoulders, leaving your arms free. Don't forget your knapsack when you head out on that hiking trip!
shorts: (noun) a bag carried by a strap on your back or shoulder
knapsack.long: You can also call a knapsack a "backpack" or a "rucksack." The word knapsack is thought to be the oldest of these terms, and while "backpack" is more often used today in the U.S., knapsack is more common in Canada. It comes from the German knappen, "to bite," and some experts believe that the name evolved from the fact that soldiers carried food in their knapsacks.
examples: With no knapsack and her heavy crash bracelets missing, Tally felt practically naked.
I took my daybook out of my knapsack and found the next blank page, the second to last.
Matching suede knapsacks and headbands were probably all the rage in Switzerland, I thought.
Off he went down the empty hallways of Permian High School, happy and cheerful, the mailgrams from Nebraska tucked safely away in his knapsack.

laconically.description: Anything that's spoken laconically gets right to the point using very few words. If the characters in your new play speak laconically, you'll write more stage directions than dialogue.
shorts: (adverb) in a dry laconic manner
laconically.long: This adverb comes from a Greek root, Lakonia, the name of a region in ancient Greece known for its citizens' skill at making convincing arguments using very few words. If your best friend has a similarly terse style, that means they also speak laconically. Talking this way makes speeches shorter, debates quicker, and conversations full of long silences.
examples: “What shall we do exactly?” asked Mr. Morris laconically.
“Count me in, Professor,” said Mr. Quincey Morris, laconically as usual.
“You’ll have to do something,” the candy woman told the manager laconically.
“My guess,” he offered laconically, “is there are more buyers today than sellers.”
“My radar clocked you going seventy-five miles an hour in a sixty-mile zone,” he said laconically.

latrine.description: a public toilet in a military area
shorts: (noun) a public toilet in a military area
examples: “Our son, your son, you do not want him cleaning latrines.”
Thus, our spittoons and garbage dumps joined our latrines to form the first agricultural research laboratories.
La Saline-on-Garbage: the air sharp with the smell of rotting oranges, sour with the smell of latrines shared by many.
The thatch roof and cracked unpainted walls bothered Ugwu, but not as much as the cavernous pit latrine in the outhouse with a rusting zinc sheet drawn across it to keep flies out.

shorts: (adverb) in a lofty manner
examples: “Ginny’s got other brothers to set her an example, Mother,” said Percy loftily.
It must have cost a good deal of Estraven’s money, that money I had loftily handed over to him in Mishnory.
Lyra imagined the Chaplain speaking loftily, listening to the star daemons’ remarks, and then nodding judiciously or shaking his head in regret.
Madness, in my admittedly limited experience, is accompanied by no superpowers; being mentally unwell doesn’t make you loftily intelligent any more than having the flu does.

lorry.description: a large low horse-drawn wagon without sides
shorts: (noun) a large low horse-drawn wagon without sides
examples: The wounded were left in the lorries to wait.
A lorry went past, making our car wobble and, for a few seconds, obscuring our view of the hoarding.
The roar of the guns makes our lorry stagger, the reverberation rolls raging away to the rear, everything quakes.
As it crawled up the steep incline, a young man jumped out and ran alongside, carrying a wood block, ready to throw it behind the back tire if the lorry were to roll back.

While some of the insurgent groups active in Afghanistan receive only general guidance from their leaders, the Taliban are believed to be somewhat hierarchical, with lower-ranking field commanders often taking directions and orders from their leaders across the border.

louse.description: A louse is a tiny insect that lives on the skin of animals and people. If you find a louse in your hair, you'll have to treat your scalp to get rid of any of its friends that might still be lurking there.
shorts: (noun) wingless usually flattened bloodsucking insect parasitic on warm-blooded animals
louse.long: Since they tend to travel in groups, the plural form of louse, lice, is much more common than the singular. Lice are small parasites that live on skin cells, blood, or other tiny bits of some host animal. If you're the host animal, you'll probably have an itchy head, and anyone who borrows your pillow or wears your hat will likely get lice too. A louse, informally, is also "an obnoxious person."
examples: Roaches here, mice, flies, lice and even a snake or two.
“This,” the expert said scratching the top of his head, “is the magnified image of a head louse.”
When people took sick, their temperatures rose and caused the body lice to seek more hospitable abodes.
They don’t believe because I’m some poor refugee kid who smells like pickles and garlic, and has lice, and I’m probably making up stories to feel important.

malicious.description: Someone who is malicious enjoys hurting or embarrassing others. If you're writing a book about good and evil, you'll want to come up with a truly malicious character to do all the bad stuff.
shorts: (adjective) having the nature of or resulting from malice
malicious.long: Malicious is the adjective based on the noun malice, which means the desire to harm others. Both words come from the Latin word malus, for bad. If someone is malicious he doesn't just make bad things happen; he loves to make bad things happen.
examples: A small, malicious, treacherous man, as stupid as he is cruel.
One false move, or one malicious report, and she was a parole violator.
When his malicious stare fell back on Thomas, he had one last thing to say.
I nodded and smiled back, then I realized there was something malicious in her smile.

monotonous.description: When something goes on and on and on and on and on, the same way, for a long time, that's monotonous. Monotonous things are boring and repetitive, like that long story you've heard your brother tell a hundred times before.
shorts: (adjective) sounded or spoken in a tone unvarying in pitch
monotonous.long: Ever hear a song that just sounds like the same thing over and over? Ever hear a dog that keeps barking all day? Or a voice that's dull and unchanging in tone? All those things are monotonous: they don't change much, and they're dull as dishwater. Anything tedious or humdrum is probably monotonous. If someone says you're being monotonous, try to vary your tone of voice or the things you're talking about.
examples: From the forest came the monotonous tick of a beetle.
He started talking in this very monotonous voice, and picking at all his pimples.
The first stop was the south-east corner, where Foremole and his crew had a monotonous task: night and day they monitored the grounds for sounds of tunneling.
If you want to get more out of life, Ron, you must lose your inclination for monotonous security and adopt a helter-skelter style of life that will at first appear to you to be crazy.

morphia.description: an alkaloid narcotic drug extracted from opium; a powerful, habit-forming narcotic used to relieve pain
shorts: (noun) an alkaloid narcotic drug extracted from opium; a powerful, habit-forming narcotic used to relieve pain
examples: "Do you suppose they have morphia powders in America?"
But even morphia could not fully dull the horror of this event.
There is nothing anyone can do in a case like that, except give morphia, and wait.”
However, the action of both heart and lungs improved, and Van Helsing made a subcutaneous injection of morphia, as before, and with good effect.

munition.description: Munitions are a collection of weapons and any equipment that goes with them. An army's cache of guns and bullets are its munitions.
shorts: (noun) weapons considered collectively
(verb) supply with weapons
munition.long: You'll usually see the noun munitions in its plural form, since it refers to arms and ammunition collectively, as a group. The word comes up mostly in discussions of wars and battles and the military. A munitions factory is the place where these supplies are made, and a munitions worker is someone who labors there. As a verb, munition means "to supply with weapons." The Latin root is munitionem, "a defending or protecting."
examples: Which of the following would be classified as munitions?
“I know a man who works in the munitions plant,” Uncle Moshe whispered.
They w as doing a lot of hiring at a munitions plant in California and people was saying that the pay was supposed to be good.
She even induced Winston to mortgage yet another of his evenings by enrolling himself for the part-time munition work which was done voluntarily by zealous Party members.
An argument that he had "essential" enamelware workers wouldn't have meant anything to the decision makers, but the argument that we were essential to Germany's munitions production did.

mutter.description: When you mutter, you mumble under your breath, often in an angry way. You might mutter to yourself as you clean graffiti off your garage, for example.
shorts: (verb) talk indistinctly; usually in a low voice
(noun) a low continuous indistinct sound; often accompanied by movement of the lips without the production of articulate speech
mutter.long: An irritable teenager might mutter when her parents make her get off the couch and mow the lawn, and your uncle might mutter at the television every night when he watches the news. When someone mutters, she speaks in a low voice, either to herself or to another person. Mutter was originally moteren in the fourteenth century, and it comes from a Proto-Indo-European root, mut, which was most likely imitative — in other words, it sounds like its meaning.
examples: Tyson muttered in his sleep and turned over.
“I fail to see how that is at all relevant,” the trickster god muttered, but he didn’t move.
And Wang Lung, without knowing what he said, muttered forth, “Well, and I do not know that I want anything.”
“Electricity really does make things easier,” he muttered to himself, but that was just the kind of statement that aroused Father Mulrooney’s scorn.

nauseate.description: To nauseate one’s friends is to make them disgusted, sick to their stomachs, or ill. Generally this is best achieved by serving foul food or sharing someone’s deepest secrets with a sworn enemy.
shorts: (verb) upset and make nauseated
nauseate.long: The first seafaring cultures were most likely Polynesian, but the Romans (who spoke Latin) came up with the word for seasickness that stuck: nausea.  When the ocean is too rollicking, it’s likely to nauseate the ship’s passengers.  There’s plenty more examples out there that can nauseate even the most hearty among us.  Often just the thought of some culinary oddities can do the trick: oyster casserole, tripe, or fried crickets — just to name a few.
examples: Jason’s head hit the asphalt with a nauseating conk.
He rests a hand on my shoulder, patting it affectionately, and his touch nauseates me.
Sefia’s eyes unfocused as she slid, dizzy and nauseated, through the currents of his life.
She looked a little nauseated and held it as gingerly as if it were something recently dead.

oblique.description: If something is oblique, it has a slanting position or direction. In figurative use, oblique means indirect or purposely misleading. "What is two plus two?" "Fish!" as an answer is completely oblique.
shorts: (adjective) slanting or inclined in direction or course or position--neither parallel nor perpendicular nor right-angled
(noun) a diagonally arranged abdominal muscle on either side of the torso
oblique.long: In math, this adjective refers to geometric lines or planes that are not parallel or perpendicular to a line or surface. A playground is positioned at an oblique angle to the ground. By correcting the clerk's "Mrs." with "That's Ms. now," the woman made an oblique reference to her change in marital status.
examples: It caught the oblique light spilling in from the hallway.
All this came through in small, oblique spurts in his conversation.
On the far right was a large house that looked straight to the most oblique curve in the river.
He had apologized to me many times in many ways before, but his apologies had always been oblique, “Eat with me, Dana. Sarah is cooking up something special.”

onslaught.description: Onslaught is a military term that refers to an attack against an enemy. It's safe to say that no one wants to be caught on the receiving end of an onslaught, because there will be lots of danger, destruction and probably death.
shorts: (noun) (military) an offensive against an enemy (using weapons)
onslaught.long: One way to help you remember the brutal meaning of onslaught is through the word's English origin, slaught, meaning "slaughter." But onslaught can be used in non-military ways, too. It can mean a barrage of written or spoken communication, like an onslaught of emailed birthday wishes. Taken individually, the birthday wishes are nice but an onslaught is too many, too fast, all at once. Onslaught can also mean a sudden and severe start of trouble. For example, if your office is unprepared for the onslaught of flu season, the entire sales force will be home sick at the same time.
examples: Silently fighting off an onslaught of tension and hostility, they broke camp.
The grease on the glass that covered the photograph showed the frequency of these affectionate onslaughts.
The nephew was crouching beside his uncle now, trying to protect him from further onslaughts—without risking his life by hitting the Lombard back.
He may be stern; he may be exacting; he may be ambitious yet; but his is the sternness of the warrior Greatheart, who guards his pilgrim convoy from the onslaught of Apollyon.

opalescent.description: If you're familiar with the way that the gemstone opal shimmers like a pearl, then you'll understand that something opalescent reflects the light in the same way.
shorts: (adjective) having a play of lustrous rainbow colors
opalescent.long: Opal is a beautiful mineral with an almost magical, layered reflective quality that catches the eye the way a pearl does. Something opalescent has that same reflective quality. High-quality guitars, for example, often have opalescent inlays in the fingerboard that are not only beautiful but also useful. They can help the guitar player find her way around the instrument. Don't be fooled by imitations! Many fake jewels have an opalescent quality that mimics real pearl, but it's plastic, all the same.
examples: Moonlight floods the bedroom, shimmers the walls, opalescent.
The nixies begin to surface, looking at us with hungry, opalescent eyes.
The logs are dark brown and shiny, and they reflected opalescent colors in the beam of my head lamp.
I noticed she was very white, the skin of her shoulder almost blue, opalescent, unbelievably pale considering where she lived.

ostracize.description: If you banish someone or ignore him, you ostracize him. When the Iranian president claimed that the Holocaust was a hoax, he was ostracized by the international community.
shorts: (verb) expel from a community or group
ostracize.long: Ostraka is an ancient Greek word for pottery shard.  Thousands of years ago, in the Greek city of Athens, there was a public process where you would write the name of someone you wanted to kick out of town on a broken ceramic fragment.  If enough Athenians wrote the same name, that person was sent away for ten years. This process was called an ostracism.
examples: I want to see the kingdom ostracize him.
“So, have you been ostracized from your little crowd of devotees?”
But he did allow himself to be persuaded, otherwise he would have been ostracized.

With their heads down disconsolately, the chaplain, Major Major and Major Danby moved toward their jeeps in an ostracized group, each holding himself friendlessly several feet away from the other two.

palatial.description: Knowing that the adjective palatial is derived from the same Latin word as palace gives you a good sense of its meaning: magnificent, reminiscent of a home fit for a king.
shorts: (adjective) relating to or being a palace
palatial.long: The Palatine (Collis Palatium in Latin) is the center of Rome’s famed Seven Hills. Tradition holds that it was the location on which Romulus founded the city, and it became a prestigious site for powerful Romans—including emperors—to build large, lavish homes. Palatium made its way into every Romance language and beyond: it became palazzo in Italian, palacio in Spanish, and palast in German. Palace entered English via the Old French palais. Power, affluence, extravagance: these are the qualities that should come to mind when you encounter the word palatial.
examples: “It’s not exactly palatial, so there’s going to be a lot of togetherness,” Mom said.
One day, when she was at the market, she saw an old man selling a painting of a palatial estate.
You ride through one of the richest neighborhoods in Johannesburg, past palatial mansions and huge money.
By prison standards, this was palatial, but the rooms were damp and musty and received very little natural light.

pallid.description: Santa looks a little pallid, meaning that he has a pale complexion, from spending too much time at the North Pole. A few days in Hawaii might do wonders to add color to his pale, bearded face.
shorts: (adjective) abnormally deficient in color as suggesting physical or emotional distress
pallid.long: Pallid means pale, or lacking color. It's often used together with complexion to describe someone who has a pale face, either due to a lack of sunshine or some kind of emotional distress. A reclusive author could be pallid from spending too much time indoors. His books can also be called pallid if they're lacking in color and excitement.
examples: North and further north they ran, while the pallid noontide came and went and the twilight wrapped itself again around the world.
The only people in the waiting room besides Doctor Nolan and me were a pallid man in a shabby maroon bathrobe and his accompanying nurse.
And at each call a little group separates itself off, a small handful of dirty, pallid soldiers, a dreadfully small handful, and a dreadfully small remnant.
There weren’t multiple charms on it now, but just one: a white-gold crescent, pallid and radiant, looking just as though it had been plucked down from the sky.

parapet.description: A parapet originally meant a defensive mini-wall made of earth or stone that was built to protect soldiers on the roof of a fort or a castle. Now it indicates any low wall along the roof of a building, the edge of a balcony, the side of a bridge, or similar structure.
shorts: (noun) a low wall along the edge of a roof or balcony
parapet.long: When drawing castles, the most remarkable feature is the parapet on the top of the towers — the notches in the parapet were designed for soldiers to stand in but have come to look like a larger version of the crown of the king inside. Now, parapets are more likely to keep you from falling off a roof than protect you from enemy soldiers trying to storm the building.
examples: Where would you most likely find a parapet?
Butler could have taken them from the parapet.
We toss the bits of rat over the parapet and again lie in wait.
She was about to say as much when she saw the battlements ahead, long parapets built into the very stone of the mountains on either side of them.
Livid with rage he clawed the foul mess from his eyes and saw Constance leaning over the parapet with a wicked grin of delight on her striped muzzle.

patronizing.description: If you are patronizing, you tend to speak down to others, acting as though you are smarter, classier, or just plain better than anyone else. For the record, your snobby attitude is not impressing anyone.
shorts: (adjective) (used of behavior or attitude) characteristic of those who treat others with condescension
