shorts: (noun) the act of causing something to move up and down (or back and forth) with quick movements

stir.description: To stir is to mix something up. You can literally stir cake batter with a spoon, or figuratively stir someone's emotions by writing them a heartfelt letter.
shorts: (verb) move an implement through
(noun) a rapid active commotion
stir.long: You can stir muffin batter with a wooden spoon, and stir in a cup of blueberries. When people stir, they start to move after being still or asleep: "It was only five o'clock, but he could hear the kids start to stir." And when something stirs you, it brings up some emotion: "That music always stirs up my sad memories." Stir shares a root with the Old Norse styrr, "tumult or disturbance."
examples: Sam stirred in his chair, and looked at the farmer with an unfriendly eye.
He felt Frolic stir and turn in his light puppyish slumber, probably dreaming of birds and chipmunks to chase.
The first minority candidate ever elected to the board, her tenure had been as stirring as it was controversial.
“Wow, this thing sure stirs up some memories,” G’ma says, grunting as she bends at the waist to remove the Green Book.

call down.description: summon into action or bring into existence, often as if by magic
shorts: (verb) summon into action or bring into existence, often as if by magic
examples: I called down from the top of the stairs, “Are you still here?”
He called down curses on her head, ordered her on his authority as her father to open that door!
“Reek,” his lordship called down from Blood’s high saddle, “you stink. I can smell you clear across the yard.”
From the veranda above them, Lillian called down to her husband, “When are you going to check in at the base, sugah?”

shorts: (verb) censure severely or angrily
examples: Bits of litter chewed up by the mowers lay scattered on the grass.
I thought Grover might chew up his reed pipes in anxiety, but he straightened up and brushed off his T-shirt.
There’s no bell by the door, or there was a bell, but it’s been dismantled, or chewed up by a wild animal, only a bunch of ravaged wires sticking out.
Soon the ancient coin would fall, and the walls would cave in, and the water would crush them in seconds, their broken bodies chewed up inside it for the scavengers.

lecture.description: When your teacher stands up in front of you and teaches by talking about the latest chapter you've read or explaining how to do a new math problem - he is giving a lecture.
shorts: (noun) a speech that is open to the public
(verb) deliver a lecture or talk
lecture.long: A lecture is most often used to describe a method of teaching, particularly popular in college, where professors give organized talks as lessons to large groups of students. It is not quite as positive when children level the term at their parents — "Don't lecture me!" — for criticizing their clothes, their friends or their music. Lecture can also be used to describe any public talk, most often by an expert.
examples: “Here’s a scrape! Do let me bring that wicked boy over to explain and be lectured. I can’t rest till I get hold of him.”
It’s been nice, working at Jimmy’s with you guys, eating whatever I want and not having anyone look at me funny or lecture me.”
Once, I asked Amma why she was always lecturing me about being good, and she told me it was because she didn't want me to end up in jail.

I have lectured in Negro colleges and some of these brainwashed black Ph. D. ’s, with their suspenders dragging the ground with degrees, have run to the white man’s newspapers calling me a ‘‘black fanatic.

lecturing.description: The noun lecturing refers to giving an instructional talk on some subject — usually in front of a class or a group of people. Despite your lecturing, the safety rules have not sunk in for this driver's ed class. Too many of the students still think it's okay to roll through a stop sign.
shorts: (noun) teaching by giving a discourse on some subject (typically to a class)
lecturing.long: Lecturing has lecture as its base word. It's from the Latin word lectura, meaning a reading or lecture. Lecturing can mean an instructional talk or it can take the form of a stern, one-sided talk. Your kids may be used to the lecturing you do at home, but that doesn't mean they like it. If you notice they roll their eyes every time you start a sentence, you may want to consider dialing back a little on the lectures.
examples: He took a pose like he was lecturing the crowd, right next to Rachel.
But instead of lecturing the girl about figuring things out for herself, Vola crouched down to study the elephant.
After lecturing for an hour, Anthony got to the point: She asked the potential jurors not to return a verdict of “guilty” if chosen to determine her fate.
I thought of lecturing her on the respect due one's bedmate in our society, but I no longer deluded myself that I either knew the society or where I fitted into it.

shorts: (verb) censure severely or angrily
examples: “A bawling out would have been better,” he said.
“Phil saw him in the office getting bawled out for it.”
She began to cry then, bawling out like a frightened child.
“Why am I picking on you every day? Why don’t I ever bawl out those other layabouts?”

rebuke.description: If you receive a rebuke, it means that you have been reprimanded, or scolded. You're sure to get a rebuke if you forget to do your math homework four days in a row.
shorts: (noun) an act or expression of criticism and censure
(verb) censure severely or angrily
rebuke.long: The word rebuke can be a verb, meaning to sternly reprimand or scold, but it can also be a noun, because a rebuke is the result of being scolded. The root comes from the Old French rebuchier and means "to hack down," or "beat back." A rebuke, then, is meant to be critical and to chide — in today's terms, a rebuke is verbal smack-down!
examples: When Nasser shifted in his seat, there were immediate rebukes.
Thomas knew the rebuke should’ve stung, but his mind was too preoccupied.
The sound was sharp—seasoned pine on hardwood—and rang out like a rebuke.
There was rebuke in his voice but a gentle, guarded rebuke, not the hostility he had revealed to Archie.

trounce.description: When you trounce someone, you win decisively. If you win a chess match in three moves, you trounce your opponent.
shorts: (verb) beat severely with a whip or rod
trounce.long: When a professional tennis player is in the midst of a tournament, she hopes to trounce her rival, and an ambitious speller might dream of the day she competes nationally and trounces all the other competitors. A victorious army can also be said to trounce the enemy. The origin of trounce is uncertain, though one theory has the French troncer, or "cut a piece off from," as its root.
examples: It was the same expression she wore when she had thoroughly trounced me in checkers.
“You trounced me these last two terms, I was bound to catch a break sooner or later. I got five talents even this term.”
The ship passed over Nuremberg, where fringe politician Adolf Hitler, whose Nazi Party had been trounced in the 1928 elections, had just delivered a speech touting selective infanticide.

In June of that year, Ulbrickson’s varsity had attempted to redeem itself at the annual Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta in Poughkeepsie, New York, but Cal had trounced them again, by five lengths this time.

shorts: (verb) censure severely or angrily
examples: Either way, they were angry at having been chewed out.
It is to the left's advantage that this is fundamentally an age of interdependence, not isolationism.
I wondered if he was still inside the farmhouse, getting chewed out by Mr. D. “Grover wont get in too much trouble, will he?”
As I made my way to the end, carefully skirting an officer chewing out a guy with a badly knotted tie, it dawned on me that I had reported to boot camp.
Currently, the Department was being sued by a stockbroker who had been pulled over and then chewed out by a correction officer for speeding, Testo told us, sounding tired.

rag.description: A torn bit of old fabric is a rag. You might use a rag to dust the bookshelf or scrub the bathtub, but you wouldn't want to wear one.
shorts: (noun) a small piece of cloth or paper
(verb) treat cruelly
rag.long: If your clothes are torn and dirty, they're also rags, and from the sense of "worthless scrap," trashy or low quality newspapers have also long been called rags. A rag is also a somewhat annoying joke, and to rag someone is to annoy or harass them. The phrase "from rags to riches" describes a classic and deeply satisfying storyline: the tale of a poor person who becomes gloriously rich.
examples: I say, drying my hands on a rag.
Then they cud up and sleep on the rag—a bedroom.
When she got closer, she saw that he was a northman, very tall and thin, huddled in a ragged fur cloak.
When you look at the moon through a telescope you cannot see mountains, but the ragged terminator indicates that mountains are there.

tantalize.description: When you tantalize people, you torment them in a specific way — by showing them something they want but can’t have. You could tantalize people with cavities and nut allergies by eating pecan pie in front of them.
shorts: (verb) harass with persistent criticism or carping
tantalize.long: The word tantalize comes from a Greek story about a guy named Tantalus who was so evil that the gods of the underworld came up with a special punishment just for him (they were really good at that). They put him in a pool of water that drained away every time he bent down to drink.  There was also a tree above his head that whisked away its juicy apples every time he tried to pick one. So, it only makes sense that to tantalize someone is to torture them with what they cannot have.

twit.description: harass with persistent criticism or carping
shorts: (verb) harass with persistent criticism or carping
(noun) someone who is regarded as contemptible
examples: She stalks away, muttering about twits who flaunt regulation.
He acted like such a twit, I’m sure he made Madam Schofield proud.
She thought about how he did not give a twit about the future, how he thought about the here and now.
Sticky, who still felt sensitive about his performance in the maze, said, “I wouldn’t say I did brilliantly. I didn’t figure out the solution or find a shortcut, I just stumbled around like a twit.”

tantalise.description: harass with persistent criticism or carping
shorts: (verb) harass with persistent criticism or carping
examples: The dominant image on the page is accompanied by three other pictures of semi-naked women, so that the entire cover consists of tantalising glimpses.
Despite a pummelling by Gennady Golovkin last year, the Polish pugilist is in his prime, meaning a tantalising offering for aficionados of the square ring.
Callow was drawn into the theatre by actors such as Paul Scofield, who seemed not so much bigger than the rest of us as more tantalising and more unknowable.

"The objects in the museum are completely mute, behind glass, and as a musician you're left to imagine what that might sound like, and it's always been the pigeon whistles that have left me tantalised."

taunt.description: A short list of people not to taunt: your big brother, nightclub bouncers, evil wizards. Taunts are insulting comments, and, unless you are a really, really fast runner, keep them to yourself.
shorts: (verb) harass with persistent criticism or carping
(noun) aggravation by deriding or mocking or criticizing
taunt.long: Taunting is often associated with large groups picking on an individual. A mob might call out a hated king from his castle with taunts and jeers. Bullying can also take the form of taunting — something that teachers, administrators, parents, and students are working together to stop.
examples: We taunted the other seventh graders going on into their classrooms.
For a while, the coins that jingled ever more loudly in the pig drowned out the taunts of the Terrible Threesome.
“I didn’t know you were so close to him,” I taunted, recalling all the times Burt had complained about the professor’s narrowness and pushing.
As much as I hated Vonetta’s meanness, her taunting was enough to prop Fern up and move her feet forward just to show Vonetta she wasn’t a baby.

thrash.description: When you thrash someone, you beat them — literally, with your fists, or figuratively, by winning a game or competition.
shorts: (verb) give a thrashing to; beat hard
(noun) a swimming kick used while treading water
thrash.long: You can describe your game plan for a chess match this way: "I plan to thrash that show-off in just ten moves." You can also threaten to physically thrash someone, like a neighborhood bully who's been known to thrash much smaller kids. Thrash was originally a sixteenth-century variation on the word thresh, which means to separate grain from wheat or another plant by beating it.
examples: My uncle groaned and thrashed about in his bed.
His body sparked and thrashed in the wires and bled as the barbs cut him.
Another corridor lined with cages, big ones though, and inside, great baying hippos and a twenty-foot alligator thrashing angrily in shallow water.
She could barely thrash her way through a few strokes, forget passing the deepwater test necessary to go off the diving boards that towered at the end of the right dock.

slam dance.description: a form of dancing in which dancers slam into one another; normally performed to punk rock
shorts: (noun) a form of dancing in which dancers slam into one another; normally performed to punk rock
(verb) dance the slam dance

slam dancing.description: a form of dancing in which dancers slam into one another; normally performed to punk rock
shorts: (noun) a form of dancing in which dancers slam into one another; normally performed to punk rock

mosh.description: To mosh is to dance in a wild, almost violent way. Fans of music like hardcore punk and thrash metal often mosh at live shows.
shorts: (verb) dance the slam dance
mosh.long: Concert-goers first began to mosh in the early 1980s while listening to bands play loud, aggressive hardcore and punk music. A "mosh pit" is the area near the stage where fans dance crazily. It became more common to mosh when grunge gained popularity in the late 80s. This verb was first spelled mash, but pronounced mosh — probably thanks to the lead singer of the band Bad Brains, who encouraged crowds to "mash it up" in his Jamaican accent.

slam.description: To slam is to close something forcefully and loudly, like when you slam your door angrily, or slam the freezer door quickly so your sister won't see the ice cream sandwiches you bought.
shorts: (verb) close violently
(noun) a forceful impact that makes a loud noise
slam.long: If you slam your finger in the door, it's going to hurt. And, if you slam your backpack onto the table, you may damage your laptop. The word slam implies violence and force. As a noun, a slam is the action or sound of slamming something. There's also a "poetry slam," when poets compete by reciting their work in front of an audience, and slam-dancing, also known as moshing, in which dancers slam into each other.

overblown.description: Overblown describes fears or concerns that are excessive, such as a overblown worry that people will notice a spot of dirt on your shoe and decide not to be your friend anymore.
shorts: (adjective) puffed up with vanity
overblown.long: Overblown is a word gardeners use to describe their flowers that, having bloomed, now hang heavy on their stems. You can use it to describe other things that are past their prime like an overblown fashion trend everyone is tired of. Another meaning is an extreme display of vanity, like the overblown decorating style of a famous actor's home — complete with photos, memorabilia from past films, and award trophies everywhere you look.

captivate.description: To captivate means to attract others, fascinating or enchanting them. Some people are able to captivate with wit and charm, others with physical beauty, still others with intelligence.
shorts: (verb) attract; cause to be enamored
captivate.long: Notice the similarity between the verbs captivate and capture. Both come ultimately from the Latin captus "taken captive." Still, while both words mean some sort of hold on someone, capture sounds harsh, as though a trap has been set, while captivate is a softer, more attractive word that suggests there might be a willingness to be caught. Robert S. McNamara, a former U.S. secretary of defense, said, "Coercion, after all, merely captures man. Freedom captivates him.”

entrance.description: As a noun, entrance means an act of entering or something that provides a way to enter something. You can make a grand entrance when you arrive at a party, as long as you can actually find the entrance.
shorts: (noun) something that provides access (to get in or get out)
(verb) put into a trance
entrance.long: Entrance has two pronunciations. If you put the accent on the first syllable, the word is a noun meaning the act of entering or the way into something ("an entrance to the building"). If the accent is on the second syllable, then entrance is a verb meaning "to enchant, charm, or enamor" — "You will be entranced by the movie; the scenery looks so real you will swear it is growing in the theater."
examples: Mr. Tushman was greeting students and parents in front of the school entrance.
She searches for the entrance, finds it, pries something open—and hops in, disappearing from view.
To keep them from coming inside, you painted the house haint blue, or you laid a broom across the entrance to the house.
As Griphook had already warned them, the liveried goblins who usually flanked the entrance had been replaced by two wizards, both of whom were clutching long thin golden rods.

catch.description: When you catch something, you grasp it or seize it in your hands, the way you catch a basketball when your friend throws it to you.
shorts: (verb) take hold of so as to seize or restrain or stop the motion of
(noun) the act of catching an object with the hands
catch.long: As a verb, catch describes grabbing and holding on. Adding the preposition on means you understand something, like when you catch on to your little brother's scheme to get out of doing chores, or to describe something that's getting popular, like a pop song that catches on then becomes a huge hit. If someone tells you there's a catch, it means there is a complication, but if a person is a catch, he or she makes a good romantic partner.

gimmick.description: A gimmick is a trick intended to attract attention. If you lure crowds to your bake sale by having cute football players handing out samples in front of your booth, that’s a gimmick.
shorts: (noun) any clever maneuver
gimmick.long: A gimmick is often used by businesses to sell a product. As a sales gimmick, your local bank might offer free microwave ovens to people who open new savings accounts. A TV show may air a live episode as a gimmick to get people to watch the show. The word sometimes has a slightly negative connotation — there’s often some flashy trickery involved in a gimmick and it doesn’t always add value to what’s being sold.
examples: If he put them on in the garage, they must be part of his sales gimmick.
The story was so logically laid out, without the gimmicks of Penguin Island.
Every business needed a gimmick, I suppose, and hers clearly worked if she could afford a pad like this.
Thoroughly worried, I went back to my desk hoping that some gimmick might emerge to salvage the like-with-like idea.

biting louse.description: wingless insect with mouth parts adapted for biting; mostly parasitic on birds
shorts: (noun) wingless insect with mouth parts adapted for biting; mostly parasitic on birds
examples: Different species of sucking and biting lice occur on the different species of farm animals.
The biting louse of sheep causes the fleece to become matted and tufts of wool are pulled out.
The biting louse may bite through the superficial layer of the skin, and cause the animal to bite and rub the part.
We should examine the parts of the skin covered by the long hair for the sucking lice; and the withers, abdomen and limbs for the biting lice.

bird louse.description: wingless insect with mouth parts adapted for biting; mostly parasitic on birds
shorts: (noun) wingless insect with mouth parts adapted for biting; mostly parasitic on birds
examples: Influence of host ecology and morphology on the diversity of Neotropical bird lice.
They are known as Mallophaga, or bird lice, though some occur on the hair of mammals.
The family of bird lice is a very extensive one, embracing many genera, and several hundred species.
It is uncommon to meet with a flock of fowls that are not hosts for one or more of the many different varieties of bird lice.

crystalize.description: cause to form crystals or assume crystalline form
shorts: (verb) cause to form crystals or assume crystalline form
examples: First of all: The pro-life/pro-choice debate hadn’t crystalized into those terms at the time.
As reported by Klarman, “Stonewall seemed to crystalize the incipient gay activism of the 1960s.”
They’re in my hair, on my skin, crystalized wings fluttering all over me, trying to crawl across my eyes and into my ears and even up my nose.

His little feet resting upon a velvet pouffe, he was sitting well back in a comfortable winged armchair, one hand grasping a small glass of wine, the other searching through a box of crystalized pineapple.

crystalise.description: cause to form crystals or assume crystalline form
shorts: (verb) cause to form crystals or assume crystalline form
examples: “But I think it worsened it, crystalised it.”
It was one of those rare times where everything crystalises around a single point.
She reasoned it out soberly, but in a way the decision had also crystalised while her former partner was beating her.
That requires rethinking the way the international system accounts for these still evolving, but soon to be crystalised, structures of governance and security.

crystallize.description: cause to form crystals or assume crystalline form
shorts: (verb) cause to form crystals or assume crystalline form
examples: We were all so sick of those crystallized lumps they choked us in our dreams.
Gradually, as the nights passed, these fictional relatives began to crystallize in their minds.
Jinny ran to and fro, as quickly as she could, picking up the sweet dark snaps, sticky with crystallized sugar.
She felt them gathering their strength inside her, felt each passing second crystallize into a map of strategic striking points wrapping around Wick’s body.

crystallise.description: cause to form crystals or assume crystalline form
shorts: (verb) cause to form crystals or assume crystalline form
examples: Apt is the world capital of crystallised fruit.
This idea was crystallised for me a few weeks ago, when two things happened on the same day.
The short-story form captures an episode or a brief period of time when a sense of loss crystallises.
Rosemary’s Baby is far more than a horror film to her: key moments in it “crystallise the larger idea of male privilege”.

elucidate.description: If you elucidate something, you explain it very clearly. If you don't understand fractions, a visit to the pie shop may elucidate the subject for you.
shorts: (verb) make clear and (more) comprehensible
elucidate.long: Elucidate, meaning "to make clear," is from the Late Latin elucidare, from the Latin prefix e-, "thoroughly," and lucidus, "clear, bright."  See the word lucid in elucidate? That's an adjective which describes someone who thinks clearly or something that is clear enough to understand.
examples: Some I have already elucidated—such as a grease spot on a passport, etc.
Which is of course idiotic in the kind of profound and multivalent way that only an English teacher could fully elucidate.
The style of teaching was Socratic in nature; ideas and theories were elucidated through the leaders asking and answering questions.
The region’s transformation from fertile woodland to eroded scrub or desert has been elucidated by paleobotanists and archaeologists.

shed light on.description: make free from confusion or ambiguity; make clear
shorts: (verb) make free from confusion or ambiguity; make clear
examples: “Yes, without guarantees, once free I could probably use my abilities to shed light on the location of your grandfather.”
Although Zlata’s book sheds light on the problems occurring in Bosnia, it wasn’t until she left that she realized the magnitude of this war.
Thomas waited, hoping that Newt or Alby would have a positive reaction to the news, maybe even have further information to shed light on the mystery.
Soon after, a friend emailed Kathy a document that seemed to shed light on the state of mind of the soldiers and law-enforcement agencies working in New Orleans at the time.

scrubby.description: sparsely covered with stunted trees or vegetation and underbrush
shorts: (adjective) sparsely covered with stunted trees or vegetation and underbrush
examples: No homes can be seen from the road; tall scrubby bushes obscure the view.
The houses all be small, but every front yard’s different—some scrubby and grassless like a baldheaded old man.
They remained always out of bow shot, but Taran caught sight of the lean, gray shapes flickering in and out of the scrubby trees.
They found their way to the depot, which was a couple of concrete warehouses in a scrubby area of waste ground where thin weeds grew between gray rocks and pools of icy mud.

scrawny.description: Scrawny is an insulting way to describe someone who's very thin and weak. You might be surprised by how lifting weights transformed your scrawny teammate to a muscular athlete by the end of the season.
shorts: (adjective) being very thin
scrawny.long: The adjective scrawny can describe a small, underweight body but it can also describe anything that's not very big or well-made — a scrawny tree that never gets any taller or fuller or a scrawny audience that disappoints the band because they were expecting a sold-out concert. Scrawny may have come from the Old Norse word skraelna, to shrivel.
examples: Alvin is about five inches shorter than me, and he’s as scrawny as a chicken wing.
Gwyneth was but twelve, a small, scrawny girl whose dark eyes and brown hair set her apart in that house of blue-eyed blondes.
I handed a scrawny Nepalese boy a fistful of rupees and received a tiny, paper-covered packet in return, emblazoned with a snarling tiger.
Hester was no beauty; she was about as plain and scrawny as a hare could be; but her eyes were marvelously colored, gold-hazel flecked with rays of deepest peat brown and forest green.

bony.description: Someone who's bony is very thin. Your cat may have been plump when he was young, and become bony as he got older.
shorts: (adjective) composed of or containing bone
bony.long: If you're so skinny that your bones are prominent, your friends might call you bony and encourage you to eat more. Another way to use the adjective bony is to mean "like bone" or "containing bone." Some animals have bony shells or protective plates — and you might not enjoy your fish dinner if it's way too bony. Bony shares a root with bone, the Old English ban, "bone or tusk."
